edu.drexel.cs.jah473.datastructures

Class KDTree<E extends KDPoint>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.drexel.cs.jah473.datastructures.KDTree<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the data stored in this KD tree, must be subclass of KDPoint
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Iterable<E>, Collection<E>

    public class KDTree<E extends KDPoint>
extends Object
implements Collection<E>, Serializable
    Class to represent a dynamic KD tree data structure. Supports efficient k-nearest neighbor, radius, bounding box, and range searches. Also supports machine learning classification and regression of data points. Insertion, removal, and membership tests are performed in logarithmic time.

    All data points are stored in leaf nodes. The default maximum number of data points per node is 5, but this can be overridden using the alternate constructor. The maximum may be violated only if the node contains duplicate points.

    The tree is built in nlog2n time using a unique splitting algorithm. Rather than choosing the median of the data set as the splitting point, the algorithm chooses the point which most closely cuts the data set in half. This point may or may not actually be the median. The splitting algorithm avoids creating empty nodes by cycling to a different dimension if it cannot find a point that splits the data. The tree is guaranteed to be relatively balanced after it is initially built, but may become unbalanced after several insertions or deletions. If a series of many insertions and/or deletions are made post-construction, the programmer may wish to rebuild the tree by instantiating a new KDTree object using the updated set of data.

    This class implements the Collection interface.
    Author:
    Justin Horvitz
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • iterator

        public Iterator<E> iterator()
        Returns an iterator for this tree. The iterator is guaranteed to traverse points in the order they are stored in the tree from left to right, however this ordering is not completely sorted on any particular dimension unless k = 1, in which case the KD tree is essentially a binary search tree.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<E extends KDPoint>
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Collection<E extends KDPoint>

      • kNN

        public List<E> kNN(KDPoint center,
                   int k)
        Finds the k nearest neighbors to the given center point.
        Parameters:
        center - the center point
        k - how many neighbors to find
        Returns:
        a list, sorted by distance, of the k data points in this tree closest to the center point

      • kNNClassify

        public <T> List<T> kNNClassify(KDPoint point,
                               int k,
                               Function<? super E,T> mapper)
        Performs a majority vote classification for the given point based on its k-nearest neighbors in this tree.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the result type of the mapping function
        Parameters:
        point - the point in question
        k - the number of neighbors
        mapper - a Function of type (? super E -> T) mapping a data point to any type
        Returns:
        a list containing the majority vote winning T value(s)

      • kNNRegression

        public double kNNRegression(KDPoint point,
                            int k,
                            ToNumberFunction<? super E,?> mapper)
        Performs a mean regression for the given point based on its k-nearest neighbors in this tree.
        Parameters:
        point - the point in question
        k - the number of neighbors
        mapper - a ToNumberFunction of type (? super E -> Number) mapping a data point to a numeric value
        Returns:
        the average of the mapped values of the k-nearest neighbors, or Double.NaN if there was no average to compute

      • pointsInBox

        public List<E> pointsInBox(double... box)
        Finds all points within the given bounding box. The number of parameters given for the bounding box must be twice the number of dimensions of this tree. The bounding box is inclusive. To construct an exclusive bounding box, consider using Double.MIN_NORMAL. If there is no restriction on a particular dimension, Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY or Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY may be passed.
        Parameters:
        box - the bounding box in the format minD0, maxD0, minD1, maxD1...
        Returns:
        a list of all points in this tree within the given bounding box

      • pointsInRange

        public List<E> pointsInRange(int dimension,
                             double min,
                             double max)
        Finds all points within the given range with respect to the given dimension. The range is inclusive. To construct an exclusive range, consider using Double.MIN_NORMAL.
        Parameters:
        dimension - the dimension number, between 0 (inclusive) and k (exclusive)
        min - the minimum value of the range (inclusive)
        max - the maximum value of the range (inclusive)
        Returns:
        a list of all points in this tree within the given range for the given dimension

        Parameters:
        point - the point in question
        radius - the radius
        mapper - a Function of type (? super E -> T) mapping a data point to any type
        Returns:
        a list containing the majority vote winning T value(s)

      • toArray

        public <T> T[] toArray(T[] a)
        Returns an array containing all of the elements in this tree. The runtime type of the returned array is that of the specified array. If all of the elements in this tree fit in the specified array, it is returned therein. Otherwise, a new array is allocated with the runtime type of the specified array and the size of this tree.
        Specified by:
        toArray in interface Collection<E extends KDPoint>
        Parameters:
        a - the array into which the elements of the list are to be stored, if it is big enough; otherwise, a new array of the same runtime type is allocated for this purpose
        Returns:
        an array containing the elements of this tree

      • toList

        public List<E> toList()
        Gets the data in this tree. Changes to the list returned will not affect this tree. The list returned is not in any particular order.
        Returns:
        a list of points in this tree.
